verses.text: I will sing forever of the LORD’s steadfast love; with my mouth I will make known Your faithfulness to all generations.
verses.comment: The psalm opens with a proclamation of God’s enduring love and loyalty, themes central to the covenant and fulfilled in Christ's eternal kingship (Luke 1:32-33).

verses.text: For I have said, ‘Your steadfast love is built up forever; in the heavens You establish Your faithfulness.’
verses.comment: God’s faithful love is everlasting, symbolized by its establishment in heaven. The language points to the eternal reality realized in Christ and the Church (Hebrews 8:5).

verses.text: You said, ‘I have made a covenant with My chosen one; I have sworn to David My servant:
verses.comment: Reference to the Davidic Covenant, foundational for Messianic expectation. This is fulfilled in Jesus, the Son of David (Romans 1:3; Luke 1:32), highlighting apostolic authority and succession.

verses.text: I will establish your offspring forever, and build up your throne for all generations.’ Selah
verses.comment: Eternal kingship, fulfilled in Christ’s everlasting reign. The continuity of David’s house spiritually manifests in the visible unity of the church (Isaiah 9:7).

verses.text: Let the heavens praise Your wonders, O LORD, Your faithfulness in the assembly of the holy ones!
verses.comment: ‘Assembly of the holy ones’ in this context denotes the heavenly host, but also foreshadows the united community of believers worshipping together (Hebrews 12:22-24).

verses.text: For who in the skies can be compared to the LORD? Who among the heavenly beings is like the LORD?
verses.comment: God’s uniqueness transcends all spiritual beings. This exclusivity prefigures the absolute supremacy of Christ above all creation (Colossians 1:15-17).

verses.text: A God greatly feared in the council of the holy ones, and awesome above all who are around Him?
verses.comment: The reverence due to God is shared by the heavenly host. The imagery reflects the worship surrounding the throne of God described in Revelation.

verses.text: O LORD God of hosts, who is mighty as You are, O LORD, with Your faithfulness all around You?
verses.comment: The phrase ‘God of hosts’ emphasizes God’s rule over the heavenly armies, showing His omnipotence and faithfulness—key elements in Messianic expectation.

verses.text: You rule the raging of the sea; when its waves rise, You still them.
verses.comment: Control of the sea often signifies divine sovereignty. Christ demonstrates this power directly by calming the storm (Mark 4:39).

verses.text: You crushed Rahab like a corpse; You scattered Your enemies with Your mighty arm.
verses.comment: ‘Rahab’ is symbolic of chaos and opposition; defeating Rahab is a metaphor for God’s victory over evil, foreshadowing Christ’s triumph over sin and death.

verses.text: The heavens are Yours; the earth also is Yours. The world and all that is in it—You founded them.
verses.comment: Affirms God as Creator, linking to Genesis. Underscores the Lord’s authority over all creation, realised fully in the New Testament in Christ.

verses.text: The north and the south—You have created them. Tabor and Hermon joyously praise Your name.
verses.comment: Mount Tabor and Hermon were famous sites in Israelite geography and worship, symbolizing the fullness of creation’s praise. Tabor later relates to the Transfiguration (Matt. 17:1-2).

verses.text: You have a powerful arm; strong is Your hand, high is Your right hand.
verses.comment: The imagery of God's ‘right hand’ points to divine power and favor—as applied to Christ in His resurrection and ascension (Acts 2:33-36).

verses.text: Righteousness and justice are the foundation of Your throne; steadfast love and faithfulness go before You.
verses.comment: God’s reign is marked by perfect justice and mercy, fully revealed in Christ, who embodies both (John 1:14; Romans 3:25-26).

verses.text: Blessed are the people who know the joyful sound, who walk, O LORD, in the light of Your face.
verses.comment: ‘Joyful sound’ could refer to liturgical worship and celebration, central to the unity of God’s people gathered in assembly (see Acts 2:46).

verses.text: They rejoice in Your name all day long, and in Your righteousness they are exalted.
verses.comment: The faithful are made righteous and lifted up; New Testament fulfillment in sharing Christ’s righteousness (Romans 5:17).

verses.text: For You are the glory of their strength; by Your favor our horn is lifted high.
verses.comment: ‘Horn’ symbolizes strength and kingship, ultimately pointing to Christ, the Anointed One (Luke 1:69), and leadership in God’s kingdom.

verses.text: For our shield belongs to the LORD, our king to the Holy One of Israel.
verses.comment: God is the true protector and sovereign. ‘Shield’ and ‘king’ here anticipate the coming Messiah as both defender and ruler.

verses.text: Once You spoke in vision to Your faithful one and said, ‘I have bestowed help on a mighty one; I have exalted one chosen from the people.
verses.comment: God’s choice of David prefigures His election of Christ, the true Chosen One (Acts 2:22), and the principle of divine appointment for leadership.

verses.text: I have found David My servant; with My holy oil I have anointed him.
verses.comment: Anointing with oil is symbolic of setting apart for a sacred task. Christ, the Anointed (‘Messiah’), fulfills this in a unique and final way.

verses.text: My hand shall be established with him; My arm also shall strengthen him.
verses.comment: Divine empowerment for David, prefiguring the unique strengthening given to Christ for His mission (Isaiah 42:6).

verses.text: The enemy shall not outwit him; the wicked shall not humble him.
verses.comment: God’s protection ensures victory over evil. The theme is ultimately confirmed in Christ’s triumph over every foe (Colossians 2:15).

verses.text: I will crush his foes before him and strike down those who hate him.
verses.comment: Divine judgment against opposition, anticipating Christ’s authority over spiritual enemies (Hebrews 2:14).

verses.text: My faithfulness and My steadfast love shall be with him, and in My name his horn shall be exalted.
verses.comment: The enduring nature of God’s covenant love, ultimately fulfilled and revealed in the Messiah, whose kingship is forever.

verses.text: I will set his hand on the sea and his right hand on the rivers.
verses.comment: This speaks of universal dominion; a prophecy pointing to the worldwide rule of the Messiah (see Matthew 28:18).

verses.text: He will cry to Me, ‘You are my Father, my God, and the Rock of my salvation.’
verses.comment: David’s relationship with God points to Jesus’ unique intimacy with the Father (John 17:1), and the New Testament teaching on spiritual sonship.

verses.text: And I will make him the firstborn, the highest of the kings of the earth.
verses.comment: ‘Firstborn’ as a title for prominence, authority, and inheritance, used in the New Testament to describe Christ’s preeminence.

verses.text: My steadfast love I will keep for him forever, and My covenant will stand firm for him.
verses.comment: Emphasizes the eternality of God’s covenant; reflected in Christ's establishment of a new and everlasting covenant (Hebrews 9:15).

verses.text: I will establish his offspring forever, and his throne as the days of the heavens.
verses.comment: The throne is pictured as perpetual, a Messianic echo fulfilled in Christ, whose reign endures eternally.

verses.text: If his sons forsake My law and do not walk according to My rules,
verses.comment: God warns of discipline for covenant unfaithfulness, yet the ultimate promise stands—underscoring the importance of obedience and perseverance.

verses.text: If they break My statutes and do not keep My commandments,
verses.comment: Obedience is essential; the spiritual application is understood as faithfulness to apostolic teaching (Acts 2:42).

verses.text: then I will punish their transgression with the rod and their iniquity with stripes.
verses.comment: God disciplines His people but does not abandon them; this concept is deepened in New Testament teaching on divine chastening (Hebrews 12:6).

verses.text: But I will not remove My steadfast love from him, nor permit My faithfulness to fail.
verses.comment: Despite human failure, God’s covenant love remains secure—a foreshadowing of the unbreakable bond in Christ (Romans 8:38-39).

verses.text: I will not violate My covenant or alter what My lips have spoken.
verses.comment: God’s fidelity to His promises is absolute; the Church maintains the same spiritual continuity through apostolic tradition.

verses.text: Once for all I have sworn by My holiness; I will not lie to David.
verses.comment: God’s oath to David ensures a perpetual dynasty. Christ’s role as true Son of David validates divine faithfulness.

verses.text: His offspring shall endure forever; his throne, as long as the sun before Me.
verses.comment: Perpetuity of the throne reflects the eternal kingdom inaugurated by Christ (Luke 1:33).

verses.text: Like the moon it shall be established forever, a faithful witness in the sky.’ Selah
verses.comment: The moon as a witness demonstrates constancy; this imaged God's trustworthy promise of messianic kingship.

verses.text: But now You have cast off and rejected; You are angry with Your anointed.
verses.comment: Psalmist laments God’s apparent rejection, recalling the historical downfall of David’s line, yet prophetically hinting towards later restoration in Christ.

verses.text: You have renounced the covenant with Your servant; You have defiled his crown in the dust.
verses.comment: Evokes deep sadness for the crown, symbolizing lost glory. Only through God’s intervention—and resurrection hope—is full restoration possible.

verses.text: You have broken down all his walls; You have brought his strongholds to ruin.
verses.comment: Imagery of devastated defenses conveys weakness and exposes the need for God’s saving intervention, fulfilled finally in Christ.

verses.text: All who pass by plunder him; he has become a scorn to his neighbors.
verses.comment: Describes humiliation, persistent in Israel’s history, reversed in the New Testament by Christ’s vindication.

verses.text: You have exalted the right hand of his foes; You have made all his enemies rejoice.
verses.comment: God’s apparent favoring of enemies is part of the mystery of redemptive suffering—fully interpreted in Jesus’ Passion.

verses.text: You have turned back the edge of his sword and have not sustained him in battle.
verses.comment: Defeat in battle highlights the consequences of separation from divine favor, and points to the need for a perfect mediator.

verses.text: You have made his splendor cease and cast his throne to the ground.
verses.comment: Represents the loss of true kingship; foreshadows Christ’s apparent defeat followed by ultimate triumph in resurrection.

verses.text: You have shortened the days of his youth; You have covered him with shame. Selah
verses.comment: Loss and shame point to the human frailty—parallels to Christ bearing our shame on the Cross.

verses.text: How long, O LORD? Will You hide Yourself forever? How long will Your wrath burn like fire?
verses.comment: The cry for restoration reflects the longing of God’s people for redemption, fulfilled in Christ and the promises made to His followers.

verses.text: Remember how short my life is! For what vanity You have created all the children of man!
verses.comment: Acknowledges the brevity of human existence; only in Christ’s resurrection do we receive everlasting hope.

verses.text: What man can live and never see death? Who can deliver his soul from the power of Sheol? Selah
verses.comment: Christ is the unique answer to this ancient question: He conquers death, granting eternal life (John 11:25-26).

verses.text: Where is Your steadfast love of old, O Lord, which by Your faithfulness You swore to David?
verses.comment: The psalmist questions the fulfillment of the promise, resonating with anticipation of messianic rescue.

verses.text: Remember, O Lord, how Your servants are mocked, and how I bear in my heart the insults of the nations.
verses.comment: The suffering of God’s servants points forward to the universal mission to unite all nations.

verses.text: With which Your enemies have mocked, O LORD, with which they have mocked the steps of Your anointed.
verses.comment: The mocking of the anointed was experienced in Christ's Passion, yet this apparent defeat ushers in victory and glory.

verses.text: Blessed be the LORD forever! Amen and Amen.
verses.comment: The doxology affirms God’s eternal praise. The double ‘Amen’ is a liturgical confirmation of faith, echoed in New Testament worship (Revelation 7:12).
